thread.title: Bali cops apparently mistake one sick killer for another
thread.title_full: Bali cops apparently mistake one sick killer for another - NY Daily News

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Bali cops apparently mistake one sick killer for another
text:
© Reuters Photographer / Reuter/REUTERS 'Chotta Rajan' escaped from a Thai hospital in 2000 and was Interpol's most wanted list. A notorious Indian fugitive killer was caught this weekend in Indonesia — but which one?
Authorities said Monday they have captured alleged crime boss Rajendra Sadashiv Nikalje, known in India as "Chotta Rajan," on the resort island of Bali.
The vicious criminal is believed to have been involved in more than 20 murders in India, Bali police spokesman Heri Wiyanto said.
"The information we have received is that the identification and verification of Chotta Rajan is going on," India's Home Minister Rajnath Singh said. "We will take necessary action once the formalities are over."
However, there seems to be some confusion over which twisted killer is in custody.
Indonesia police official Reinhard Habonaran Nainggolan had previously said that they had captured Mohan Kumar, also known as "Cyanide Mohan," a serial killer who may have killed more than 20 young women.
Kumar tricked women by promising to marry them, according to The Times of India . After sleeping with them, he would poison them with a Cyanide pill after telling them it was for birth control.
timesnews24x7 R.K.BHAT/© timesnews24x7 R.K.BHAT/Demoti 'Cyanide Mohan' was sentenced to death for three killings in 2013, but fled to Australia. "Cyanide Mohan" was sentenced to death for three killings in 2013, but fled to Australia. He was reportedly caught after arriving at the Bali airport on Sunday, according to the Washington Post .
"Chotta Rajan," meanwhile, escaped from a Thai hospital in 2000 and has been on Interpol's most wanted list for years. He was arrested Sunday after arriving at Bali's airport from Sydney after authorities followed up on tips from Interpol and Australian authorities.
Nikalje said he had been hiding in Australia for seven years and flew to Bali for vacation.
Wiyanto, the Bali spokesperson, said the previous arrest report on Kumar was wrong, and Nainggolan confirmed that Nikalje arrived in Indonesia carrying a passport using the alias Mohan Kumar.
